subject: RE: [junit] testing switch statements in method
msgSnippet: ... Humm. Is the exact title Working Effectively with Legacy Code (Paperback) ? Amazon link:
messageBody:
>Michael Feather's book "Testing legacy code"

Humm. Is the exact title "Working Effectively with Legacy Code (Paperback)"
?

Amazon link:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0131177052/qid=1141735566/sr=1-1/ref=sr_1_1
/002-8774464-9461605?s=books&v=glance&n=283155
-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of
Cédric Beust ?
Sent: Monday, March 06, 2006 10:45 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] testing switch statements in method


Joe,


On 3/6/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> So it's your choice: which do you value more? The API as it is now, or
> writing good tests? If you value the first one more, you'll have to
> settle for longer, more brittle, more expensive tests. That's a judgment
> only your team can make.


I think Kamal made it clear that changing the API was not an option, so
he's
definitely looking for an option to test an API that he has no control
over. Sad, but fairly common in my opinion.

It's already been done, but I'll repeat it: Michael Feather's book
"Testing
legacy code" contains some good advice for these kinds of situations

I envy people who have write access to 100% of the code they need to test,
they don't know how easy they have it :-)

--
Cédric
http://testng.org
